I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Asian Development Bank’s long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020)1 
highlights the need to refocus on three development agendas, one of which is inclusive growth. 
Refocusing will entail promoting greater access to opportunities for the disadvantaged through 
investments in education, health, and basic social protection.2 The regional technical assistance 
(RETA)3 will  enhance  the  capacities  of  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  and  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff in designing and applying well-defined and focused strategies 
and operational initiatives in social protection. It will undertake research and support new and 
ongoing initiatives to better understand what works under which conditions. Learning from the 
research and technical support will be disseminated through a communication program to raise 
awareness and support adoption of targeted social protection strategies and programs. The 
concept paper was approved by the Vice-President, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development, on 8 April 2008. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  ADB  has  supported  social  protection  interventions  through  loans  and  technical 
assistance since the mid-1990s. It has been successful in facilitating policy dialogues and 
research as well as in disseminating information and knowledge on social protection and safety 
nets (especially during the Asian economic crisis). Recent research on the social protection 
index (2008)4 provides policymakers with a tool to analyze and measure social protection and 
shows a complete picture of social protection in different countries. Strategy 2020 calls for ADB 
to  support  poverty  alleviation  through  a  strategy  of  inclusive  growth  that  emphasizes 
(i) increasing  economic  opportunities,  (ii)  broadening  access  to  these  opportunities, 
(iii) strengthening social protection and social safety nets, and (iv) supporting gender equity. 
ADB must be prepared to meet this demand in coordination with other development partners 
and the private sector. This RETA aims to provide ADB a clear focus for responding to the 
social protection demands of its DMCs and to build ADB’s capacity for responding to this 
growing need.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Strategy 2020 recognizes that the benefits of rapid economic growth are not reaching all 
population groups in DMCs proportionately. Large numbers of people are being left behind in 
terms of economic benefits and access to social services (footnote 1). DMCs are facing new 
challenges in making socioeconomic growth more inclusive and equitable. They have raised 
concerns  about  (i)  the  rapidly  aging  population,  (ii)  increased  internal  and  transborder 
migration,5 (iii) urbanization that is growing by 5% annually,6 (iv) increasing costs of social 
services that are barely affordable for low-income groups, (v) the rising exposure to natural 
disasters and economic crises, and (vi) the looming food crisis.

4.  Demographic transition in Asia requires building up safety nets for the elderly. 
During 2004–2025, it is estimated that the region’s population will not only expand but will also 
be reshaped by demographic shifts that may have significant implications for governments’ 
development policies and spending on basic services.7 By 2030, it is estimated that more than 
half of working age individuals (20–59 years old) in the region will each be supporting two 
persons older than 60.8 Countries will be increasingly caught in a “demographic squeeze” where 
the elderly will be providing support to their still-surviving parents and yet will have fewer 
children to rely on.9 Overall, the share of Asia’s elderly population is expected to triple between 
now and 2050. The share of the elderly in the total population of the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC) will be 30% by 2050. This will be more than the total population of the United States. The 
huge fiscal burden placed on the public pension and health care for the elderly is a serious 
concern for the years to come.   
 
5.  Migration  and  urbanization  erodes  the  traditional  family  support  system. 
Traditional  support  provided  by  families  and  communities  to  their  vulnerable  members  is 
declining and can no longer protect against major life changes. Without formal social protection 
mechanisms in place, sustainable growth will be difficult to achieve. Governments throughout 
the region are adjusting their social policies and are increasingly emphasizing the formalization 
of support systems such as social insurance to reduce the vulnerability of their populations. This 
is particularly true for major recipients of ADB support, such as the PRC, India, Indonesia, and 
the  Philippines.  This  is  also  true  for  developed  and  middle-income  countries  such  as  the 
Republic of Korea and Malaysia, where there is potential for new partnerships with ADB, as 
shown during the Asian financial crisis.  
 
6.  Social protection needs to address health risks. Expenditure on health is low. South 
Asia, for example, spends less on health than any region in the world, including sub-Saharan 
Africa, at $26 per capita per year. Lack of financing possibilities in catastrophic health cases is a 
major reason for falling into poverty. A World Bank study10 finds “nearly one quarter of people 
admitted to hospitals in India were above the poverty line when they were admitted, but were 
below the poverty line at the end of their stay because of the health expenditures they incurred.” 
Health  insurance  coverage  is  limited  and  underfinanced  in  many  countries.  While  health 
programs  are  increasingly  being  financed  through  government,  private  sector,  and  grant 
development aid, health system reforms are more and more becoming recognized as a major 
focus of development in Asia. Increasing the public share in health financing and building up 
sustainable finance and health insurance systems are key priorities in the region.  
 
7.  Social protection prevents poverty and contributes to achieving the Millennium 
Development Goals. There is a broad range of social protection programs, and most aim to 
reduce chronic poverty. Social protection focuses on building assets of the poor, ensuring 
opportunities for them to use their assets more productively, and transferring cash or quasi-cash 
through social assistance programs (food transfers, food stamps, food price subsidies), cash 
transfers (grants, noncontributory pensions), service subsidies (social housing programs, utility

subsidies), and conditional cash transfers (CCTs).11 Among the range of approaches, CCTs 
(conditioned on child and maternal health practices and school attendance) are increasingly 
receiving attention among policymakers and practitioners, based on evidence of their success in 
Latin America. Cash transfer programs are now widely supported (for example in Indonesia12 
and the Philippines)13 as an effective mechanism to reduce poverty, as well as to help achieve 
several Millennium Development Goals. They encourage greater use of public services, such as 
education and health, and provide vitally needed income support to poor households.   
 
8.  Social protection and the current food crisis. ADB’s recent report on the food crisis14 
indicates that food price inflation severely stresses the most vulnerable groups. High and rising 
food prices are threatening to reverse the gains in poverty reduction in the Asia and Pacific 
region, undermining the global fight against poverty. If high food prices persist, the goal of 
halving poverty by 2015 could be jeopardized. However, trade measures or price controls are 
not efficient ways to combat the food crisis or food price inflation. These distort markets and 
could exacerbate the situation in the international grain market. ADB has suggested that the 
best way to address the immediate difficulty is to strengthen social safety nets through targeted 
support for the poor rather than generalized food subsidies, trade measures, or price controls.15  
 
9.  Social protection helps mitigate environmental risks related to climate change. A 
range of insurance and social safety net mechanisms help in mitigating environmental and other 
risks, particularly as exposure to environmental, financial, and political shocks may not be 
automatically  reduced  as  an  economy  grows  to  middle-income  status.  Unfortunately, 
vulnerability to risks and shocks remains high for a significant proportion of the population due 
to such factors as natural disasters (which are growing concerns in light of global warming).  
 
10.  Making  social  protection  systems  more  efficient  and  inclusive  reduces  the 
financial  burden  of  the  poor.  Although  public  social  protection  systems  are  weak  in 
developing Asia, such systems are available in most countries. However, those systems have 
low  coverage  and  are  often  inefficient.  For  example,  not  more  than  25%  of  the  working 
population and their dependants in the region are covered by statutory social insurance, which 
mainly include old-age pensions and some health care benefits. With further extension and 
reform of statutory social insurance systems, coverage could reach another 5%–10% of the 
working population. The increasing integration of markets and the competition offered by the 
private sector against inefficient government systems create opportunities to provide services 
more flexibly and add reach in public–private partnerships. Partner countries and subsovereign 
entities articulate massive demand for governance reforms and advisory assistance in the 
sector.  There  is  substantial  scope  for  more  private  sector  involvement  and  public–private 
partnerships—and particularly in social insurance.  
 
11.  Gender  and  social  protection.  Gender  dimensions  in  social  protection  policies, 
strategies, and programs are very important because vulnerabilities to risk vary significantly by

gender.  Understanding  and  incorporating  gender  issues  entails  more  than  tackling  gender 
discrimination: it brings about significant benefit for pro-poor growth. Attention to gender in 
program design can enhance the efficiency of social protection and ensure better protection of 
both men and women. Hence, to achieve gender-equitable access to social protection services, 
gender issues should be an integral part of social protection policies, strategies, and programs.  
 
12.  Facing this host of issues, governments throughout the region are adjusting their social 
policies and increasingly emphasizing the need to strengthen or introduce formal and effective 
social protection systems to guarantee the security of their populations. Many of them are 
particularly interested in learning from the experiences of other countries in Asia and elsewhere, 
as well as in being exposed to emerging, new ideas.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The expected impact of the RETA is more inclusive economic growth in DMCs from 
supporting DMCs in developing and adopting social protection policies and programs. The 
outcomes are (i) increased institutional readiness of ADB in designing and implementing social 
protection policies and programs, and (ii) enhanced ADB operations in selected areas of social 
protection.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  The  key  expected  outputs  are  (i)  an  assessment  of  the  demand  and  institutional 
response and capacities of ADB and its partners that will inform programming and designing 
efforts in social protection; (ii) operational recommendations for ADB’s future support in selected 
areas of social protection, taking into account the comparative advantages of ADB and other 
development  agencies;  and  (iii)  awareness-raising  and  knowledge-sharing  activities  to 
disseminate  knowledge  and  build  capacities  in  designing  and  implementing  policies  and 
programs in selected areas of social protection. 
 
15.  Component 1: Assessment of Demand and Institutional Response. An assessment 
will be undertaken of the current and potential demand of DMCs and the nature of this demand. 
Institutional responses of ADB and other development agencies to social protection will be 
reviewed as well, highlighting the comparative advantages of ADB, social protection networks, 
and other development agencies while identifying areas where synergies can be achieved. The 
review  will  focus,  in  particular,  on  the  areas  of  pension  reform,  social  insurance,  social 
assistance,  and  conditional  cash  transfer  programs.  Component  1’s  outputs  will  be:  (i)  a 
summary of past and current initiatives of ADB, other development partners, and DMCs on the 
selected areas of social protection; (ii) identification of major lessons learned, opportunities for 
ADB  intervention,  and  potential  for  synergies  with  development  agencies  and  DMCs;  and 
(iii) operational recommendations for ADB’s future support in the selected areas.  
 
16.  Component 2: Support to New and Ongoing Initiatives. Component 2 will provide 
technical and operational support to social protection initiatives in DMCs. An initial list of social 
protection initiatives from the following regions have been identified for support: (i) pension 
assessment and reform in Central Asia, (ii) capacity building support for national social security 
reform in Indonesia, (iii) support to the establishment and initial operation of the South Asia 
Pension Forum, and (iv) capacity building support to Mongolia’s social health insurance system. 
Selection  and  validation  of  support  areas  shall  be  finalized  in  consultation  with  regional

5
operational  departments.  Support  shall  include  technical  assistance,  workshops  and 
consultations, advisory assistance, and expert inputs for designing and/or implementing priority 
initiatives. Experience from this component will feed into and inform components 1 and 3.  
 
17.  Component 3: Awareness Raising and Capacity Building. A communications and 
learning strategy will be developed to disseminate findings and experiences from components 
1 and 2. In-country briefings will be conducted to share learning from the RETA’s activities 
among DMCs and ADB staff. DMCs and ADB staff participation in international conferences 
and/or  training  on  social  protection  will  be  supported.  Online  or  other  networking  and 
knowledge-exchange  activities  on  social  protection  among  DMCs  and  ADB  staff  will  be 
facilitated. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The RETA’s cost is estimated at $1,000,000. It will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The RETA will be implemented over 18 months (August 2008–January 2010). ADB will 
be the Executing Agency through its Gender, Social Development, and Civil Society Division 
(RSGS) of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department and will be responsible for 
overall  management  and  monitoring  of  RETA  activities  in  collaboration  with  regional 
departments. Throughout the RETA period, RSGS will closely consult with and will be guided by 
regional departments and resident missions concerned. At least four projects will be included in 
the RETA.16 The RETA’s progress and outputs will be posted and updated regularly at ADB’s 
social development website with links to social protection websites.   
 
20.  The  RETA  will  require  an  estimated  34  person-months  of  consulting  services 
(3 international  consultants  with  expertise  in  social  insurance,  pension  reforms,  and  social 
assistance for a total of 12 person-months and 22 person-months of national consultants with 
similar expertise as the international consultants). The international consultants, in coordination 
with regional operational departments, will lead the assessment and the operational support to 
DMC initiatives. National consultants will provide support to the international consultants and 
assist DMCs in developing and operationalizing social protection initiatives. All consultants will 
be engaged by ADB as individuals in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix 3. RSGS will set up a review and advisory panel that will include internal and external 
scholars and practitioners who will act as reviewers and advisors to the project during the 
course of the RETA. 
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Enhancing Social Protection Initiatives in Developing Member Countries, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.  
                                                 
16  These  projects,  spread  across  ADB  operational  regions,  will  be  selected  in  consultation  with  operations 
departments on the basis of potential demand and the existing portfolio and pipeline.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (12 person-months) 
 
1.    Social Protection Specialist and Team Leader (6 person-months, intermittent) 
 
1.  The team leader will be a social protection specialist with in-depth knowledge of pension 
reforms and a solid international reputation in his or her field, a significant background in cross-
cutting issues, and field experience in Asia. Familiarity with multilateral development banks and 
ability to work in a multidisciplinary team are essential. The specialist will also act as principal 
advisor to the projects on pension reform and will ensure that the policies being developed in the 
proposed strategy are equitable, sustainable, and socially sound. The specialist will produce two 
major outputs: (i) a paper analyzing current policies and practices of selected developing member 
countries  (DMCs)  and  major  options  for  reform,  and  (ii)  a  paper  detailing  options  for  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) project and program interventions. The specialist will pay particular 
attention to issues of coverage, affordable options to expand pensions to the informal sector, 
gender dimensions, macroeconomic linkages, fiscal impacts, and institutional impacts.   
 
2.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  In collaboration with the review and advisory panel, act as a resource person and 
assist  ADB  in  coordinating  all  technical  and  logistical  aspects  of  the  regional 
technical  assistance  (RETA),  including  preparing  and  coordinating  the  final 
workshop,  country  briefings,  project-to-project  exchanges,  participating  in 
developing  member  countries  representatives  and  ADB  staff  in  international  or 
regional conferences, and editing and finalizing the RETA publication. 
(ii)  During the first 3 weeks, prepare an inception report that will be the basis of the final 
report. The inception report will build on ADB’s experience in implementing the 
social protection strategy.1 
(iii)  Visit  the  participating  social  protection  project  initiatives  in  several  DMCs  and 
discuss with government counterparts their priorities in social protection. 
(iv)  Liaise with other development and funding agencies and governments to ensure 
that  ADB’s  project  pipelines  and  other  efforts  are  consistent  with  country 
assessments and strategies.  
(v)   Consult with and assist regional operations department staff to confirm areas of 
support for the pension reforms initiative. 
(vi)  Visit projects supported by the RETA and discuss with government counterparts and 
other  relevant  stakeholders  their  needs,  demand,  constraints,  and  priorities  in 
pension reforms. 
(vii)  In collaboration with ADB’s South Asia Governance, Finance and Trade Division, 
identify requirements and provide operational recommendations in the setting up of

(viii)  Prepare  (a)  a  paper  analyzing  selected  DMCs’  current  pension  policies  and 
practices plus major options for reform while identifying good examples, areas for

options for ADB pension projects and program interventions. The papers should be

ADB staff members and DMC officials. The final drafts should be submitted for

2.  Social Assistance and Conditional Cash Transfer Specialist (3 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
3.  The specialist will be a professional with a solid international reputation in his or her field, a 
significant background in cross-cutting issues, and field experience in Asia. The specialist will act 
as principal advisor to the projects on social assistance and will ensure that the policies being 
developed in the proposed strategy are equitable, sustainable, and socially sound. The specialist 
will produce two major outputs: (i) a paper analyzing current selected DMCs’ policies and practices 
plus major options for social assistance, and (ii) a paper detailing options for ADB project and 
program interventions. The specialist will pay particular attention to issues of coverage, targeting, 
disaster  prevention  and  mitigation,  such  affordable  options  to  expand  social  assistance  as 
conditional cash transfers (CCTs) linked to education and health services, gender dimensions, 
macroeconomic linkages, fiscal impacts, and the role of CCTs in reducing poverty and vulnerability.   
 
4.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  In collaboration with the team leader, identify specific analytical and policy issues of 
concern and produce an outline to be incorporated into the inception report that will 
be the basis of the final report. 
(ii)  Consult with and assist regional operations department staff to identify and confirm 
areas of support for the initiative on social assistance and CCTs. 
(iii)  Visit projects supported by the RETA and discuss with government counterparts and 
other  relevant  stakeholders  their  needs,  demand,  constraints,  and  priorities 
regarding CCTs. 
(iv)  Liaise with other development and funding agencies and governments to ensure 
that  ADB’s  project  pipelines  and  other  efforts  are  consistent  with  country 
assessments and strategies. 
(v)  Prepare (a) a paper analyzing current selected DMCs’ policies and practices in 
social assistance while identifying good examples, areas for case studies, and good 
practices in social assistance and CCTs; and (b) a paper detailing options for ADB 
project  and  program  interventions  involving  CCTs.  The  papers  should  be 
comprehensive and impartial in their approach and be presented in a manner useful 
for ADB staff members and DMC officials. The final drafts should be submitted for 
finalization at ADB headquarters 4 weeks before the start of the regional workshop. 
(vi)  Following the responses from DMC governments, as well as from the review and 
advisory panel, recommend and prepare refinements on the papers. 
 
3.  Social Insurance Specialist (3 person-months, intermittent) 
 
5.  The specialist will be a professional with a solid international reputation in his or her field, a 
significant background in cross-cutting issues, and field experience in Asia. The specialist will act 
as principal advisor to the projects on social insurance and will ensure that the policies being 
developed in the proposed strategy are equitable, sustainable, and socially sound. The specialist 
will produce two major outputs: (i) a paper analyzing current selected DMCs’ policies and practices 
plus major options for social insurance, and (ii) a paper detailing options for ADB project and 
program interventions. The specialist will pay particular attention to issues of coverage; targeting; 
disaster prevention and mitigation; affordable options to expand health insurance coverage, and 
particularly for informal or unorganized workers and the poor; gender dimensions; macroeconomic 
linkages; fiscal impacts; and the role of social insurance in reducing poverty and vulnerability.

Appendix 3  11 
 
6.  The consultant will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  In collaboration with the team leader, identify specific analytical and policy issues of 
concern and produce an outline to be incorporated into the inception report that will 
be the basis of the final report. 
(ii)  Consult with and assist regional operations department staff to identify and confirm 
areas of support for social insurance reform, such as micro insurance and health 
insurance. 
(iii)  Visit projects supported by the RETA and discuss with government counterparts and 
other  relevant  stakeholders  their  needs,  demands,  constraints,  and  priorities  in 
social insurance reform. 
(iv)  Liaise with other development and funding agencies and governments to ensure 
that  ADB’s  project  pipelines  and  other  efforts  are  consistent  with  country 
assessments and strategies. 
(v)  Prepare (a) a paper analyzing current selected DMCs’ policies and practices in 
social insurance while identifying good examples, areas for case studies, and good 
practices in social insurance reforms; and (b) a paper detailing options for ADB 
project  and  program  interventions  in  social  insurance.  The  papers  will  be 
comprehensive and impartial in their approach and presented in a manner useful for 
ADB staff members and DMC officials. The final drafts should be submitted for 
finalization at ADB headquarters 4 weeks before the start of the regional workshop. 
(vi)  Following the responses from DMC governments, as well as from the review and 
advisory panel, recommend and prepare refinements on the papers. 
 
B.  National Consultant (22 person-months, intermittent) 
 
  1.  National Consultant at Headquarters (10 person-months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The national consultant will be based in Manila and perform tasks under the supervision of 
the team leader and staff of the Gender, Social Development, and Civil Society Division. The 
national consultant should have a strong background on social protection and cross-cutting social 
dimensions. 
 
8.  The national consultant will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Provide logistical and administrative support to the training, workshops, knowledge 
exchange, and preparation of pilot activities. 
(ii)  Assist  in  and  facilitate  communication  among  the  members  of  the  review  and 
advisory panel, international consultants, and DMC representatives. 
(iii)  Identify ways for online networking among the DMC social protection champions 
and other means to enhance their knowledge exchange. 
(iv)  Assist the team leader in overall RETA administration and the logistics for the 
studies, workshops, and publications. 
(v)  With the help of regional operations departments, collect key documents and data 
related to social protection project preparation and implementation, then input these 
to the database. 
(vi)  Collect project data on social protection for 2001–2008 loan projects. 
(vii)  Develop other databases related to social protection, such as resource persons and 
consultants,  regional  institutes,  as  well  as  nongovernment  and  civil  society 
organizations dealing with social protection. 
(viii)  Revamp the social protection website page in ADB’s external website, and regularly 
upload social protection knowledge products and events information.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
  2.  National Consultants in Participating DMCs (12 person-months, intermittent) 
 
9.  For at least four participating DMCs, one national consultant will be selected and recruited 
in  each  DMC  to  support  international  consultants  during  the  RETA  implementation.  Each 
consultant should have deep understanding of the respective DMC’s selected areas of social 
protection (i.e., pension, CCT, or social insurance) in which he or she would be assigned to work. 
The consultants will: 
(i)  Assist international consultants to assess current selected areas of social protection 
programs. 
(ii)  Review previous country studies on selected areas of social protection programs by 
other international agencies such as World Bank, International Labour Organization, 
other  bilateral  agencies,  and  private  entities  including  nongovernment  and  civil 
society organizations. 
(iii)  Review the different modes of delivering social protection programs, and, based on 
the country experience, ascertain the strengths and weaknesses of these methods, 
as applicable. 
(iv)  Assist the international consultants in collecting study-related data, drafting case 
study reports, and preparing presentations of the reports in the regional workshop or 
conference.
